original_title: Amateur Estimates of Venusian Day using Arecibo Data
original_content:
[Nathaniel Fairfield] aka [thandal] was curious about the actual rotation and axis tilt of Venus. He decided to spin up at GitHub Python repository to study the issue further, as one does. The scientific literature shows a wide range of estimates and variations for the planets revolution and axis tilt. He wondered if the real answer might be found in a publicly available set of uncalibrated delay-doppler images of Venus. These data were collected by the former Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico from 1988 through 2020.  [Thanda] observed that the planets revolution appears to be speeding up slightly, and furthermore, his estimates of the orbital axis were within 0.01 degrees of the International Astronomical Unions (IAU) values. [Note: Venus is a bit confusing  one planetary revolution, 243 days, is longer than its year, 225 days].
Estimations of Venusian Orbital Period, [Thandal] Estimates in GreenAligning and calibrating the raw data was no trivial task. You have to consider the radars (Earths) position and time, as well as Venus. Complicating the math even more, some times the radar was operated in a bistatic mode, with the Green Bank Telescope in West Virginia being the receiver.
Theres a lot of interesting signal processing going on here. The Doppler-delay data consists of images that are 80918092 array of complex values, has to be mapped onto the Venus geoid.  Then by using various surface features, one can compare their positions vs time and obtain an estimate of rotational speed and tilt. If these kinds of calculations interest you, be sure to check out [Thandal]s summary report, and also take note of the poliastro Python astrodynamics library. Why is this important? One reason to better plan future missions.
title: ヴィーナスの回転速度と軸傾斜の推定に関する研究結果および計算手法
body: 宇宙試験や惑星の回転と軸傾斜についてのデータを調査した[thandal]がGitHub Pythonリポジトリで公開されているヴィーナスのデータを分析。確認した結果、ヴィーナスの公転速度がわずかに速くなっていることや、軌道軸の推定値が国際天文学連合（IAU）の値とほぼ一致することを発見しました。
